Charles Dickens.Action: Acknowledges and appreciates the warm reception from the crowd, appearing sincere and moved by their enthusiasm.
Shows uncertainty and hesitation before addressing the crowd, indicating humility and openness.
Speaks warmly to the welcoming crowd, expressing appreciation.
Throws pen down in frustration and snaps at housekeeper Mrs. Fisk.
Plays accordion and sings to himself in a playful, light-hearted manner.
Accepts interruption politely by saying he'll be right down.
Takes charge of domestic decisions such as choosing wallpaper, doors, blinds, and bookcases, showing careful attention to detail and leadership in household matters.
Rejects redecorating of his study, showing a reluctance to allow improvements or outside input, which could suggest inflexibility or stubbornness.
Staggers back in shock at the high cost of the parlour mantle, indicating possible lack of financial preparation or unawareness of expenses.
Despite the shock at the cost, promptly arranges to pay Signor Mazzini and proceeds with business, suggesting responsible follow-through and handling of obligations.
Comes down the stairs thundering and admits losing track of time, implying some degree of disorganization or poor time management.
Refuses to spend money on a cab, insisting on walking with Forster to lengthen their days, showing a practical and purposeful approach.
Remains silent and composed during Forster's angry confrontation with publishers, lips pressed tightly while others argue.
Turns his back on publishers after blunt and dismissive exchanges; leaves abruptly without softening politeness.
Bluffs about a new book to secure an advance, showing some strategic engagement despite financial stress.
Sends urgent letters begging for money, exhibiting vulnerability but also burdening others.
Bluffs about having a new book to secure an advance.
Sweeps out of the room abruptly, showing confidence and control in negotiation.
Is in financial difficulty, needing money urgently and selling his own autographs publicly.
Hides from Thackeray to avoid mockery about his reviews, showing self-consciousness without confrontation.
Makes dry complaints about the club's service and food in the presence of friends, indicating candidness but no malice.
Greets Thackeray and engages in conversation despite Thackeray’s somewhat biting tone.
Dismisses negative reviews about his work casually and without bitterness.
Responds to criticism with a tight smile and visible irritation.
Complains about London’s overcrowding and fog but remains engaged with friends.
Insists on giving a speech for the Children's Refuge despite feeling exhausted.
Stops himself when mentioning the new commission, showing hesitation.
Expresses feeling of having run out of ideas and feeling old, showing self-doubt and creative block.
Stops himself mid-sentence when confronted about his new commission, indicating hesitation or avoidance.
Maintains some ritualistic preparation for writing, suggesting a methodical and disciplined approach despite creative struggles.
Seeks clarity about the topic of his next book commission, showing professional inquiry and engagement.
Admires the nursemaid Tara who is liked by his son Charley
Disputes about the candle stub but ultimately warm with Kate as they joke
Expresses frustration about financial troubles openly with Kate
Complains about money issues yet continues to give to beggars and wants better living conditions
Insists on making small resources (a candle stub) last longer, showing frugality and awareness of finances.
Recognizes the dangers of debt and speaks with intensity about financial caution.
Complains about financial hardship despite living beyond means (moving to bigger house, ordering new fixtures, giving money to beggars).
Expresses dissatisfaction and doubts about his career path, wishing he had become a journalist or lawyer.
Expresses pleasure and support at the news of a new child ('Of course! Splendid.'), showing care and genuine warmth.
Appears lost in his own thoughts and somewhat inattentive during conversation, potentially indicating emotional distance or preoccupation.
Distracted and lost in his own thoughts during conversation with Kate.
Responds attentively and kindly to Kate's news about the doctor, showing emotional intelligence.
Puts his hand on young Charles' head to comfort him and reassures him 'It’s all right, Charlie. I’m here. You’re safe.'
Interacts playfully and kindly with each of his children, using different voices, making them laugh, and showing attention to their feelings and behaviors.
Comforts young Charles during a frightening moment and calmly guides him to overcome his fear.
Interacts playfully and attentively with each of his children, using different voices and showing engagement.
Pulls a coin from Charley's ear to his delight and playfully teases him about not washing behind his ears.
Notes the look of adoration on Charley's face and acknowledges Charley's relationship with Tara warmly.
Listens with interest to Tara's story about Christmas Eve and spirits, reflecting thoughtfully.
Pulls a coin from Charley's ear playfully and interacts warmly and attentively with children and adults.
Engages thoughtfully with Tara's story about fairies and reflects on it.
Delivers a speech at the Benefit for the Children's Refuge, attracting well-dressed patrons and shaking hands, showing social skill and public presence.
Offers sympathy and concern for poor and marginalized characters, including barefoot urchins, and challenges Mr. Grimsby's harsh views.
Struggles to control his temper but chooses to leave the conversation rather than argue heatedly with Mr. Grimsby.
Engages sincerely with difficult questions about poverty and social injustice, showing tolerance and thoughtful concern.
Commands the toothless man to release the children and threatens to involve the police.
Attempts to chase after the man and the children despite the dangers of the street.
Collapses exhausted in the church graveyard showing physical and emotional impact of the encounter.
Shrinks against the wall when confronted with the Lone Mourner's malice, recoils at 'Humbug'.
Greets Mrs. Fisk politely and hands her his hat upon entering his home.
Appears oblivious and mutters 'Humbug!' despite family waiting for him, showing disengagement.
Speaks to himself furiously about his story's miserly character, showing passion for moral lessons about selfishness.
Thanked the gentlemen for their opinion but decisively rejected their advice and ripped up the cheque.
Expressed anger and contempt by calling others 'scaly-headed vultures' and 'money grubbing, scum-sucking'.
Volunteered to pay for the entire project himself and handle distribution personally despite the financial risk.
Spoke coldly to Forster and gave an ultimatum to help or not, showing rigidity in communication.
Demonstrated determination and conviction about his project, showing sincerity in his intentions.
Politely greets Mr. Haddock and thanks him, showing courteousness.
Quietly observes the unkempt state of the solicitor's office, no complaint or criticism.
Shakes his head, repulsed, at the suggestion of debtors' arrest and prison
Attempts to negotiate payment terms fairly with Haddock despite own anxiety
Negotiates to defer payment of a large legal bill despite his financial difficulties, attempting to secure additional funds on credit.
Shows visible anxiety and becomes pale and unwell when discussing financial matters, indicating stress.
Refuses to take harsh legal action against bankrupt defendants (debtor's prison), showing moral judgment but potentially limiting leverage.
Claps Forster on the shoulder when found looking after him
Shrugs off concern about his health and stalks off
Uses inscription 'To Papa. Love, Charles' to help his father pawn a book

Delegates the repayment details to Forster confidently.
Walks carefully as if he might faint and appears physically unwell but continues working.

Interrogates Tara about the Penny Dreadful magazine and shows interest in her reading skills, then makes a thoughtful book trade offer.
Refuses to be interrupted under any circumstances, indicating a strong focus on work.
Invites Tara to read his work and share thoughts, showing openness and friendliness.
Encourages interaction with the character Scrooge, trying to befriend him despite Scrooge's standoffishness.
Laughs off Scrooge's negativity and persists with playful engagement.
Oblivious pacing and fixation on character creation, somewhat self-absorbed moment.
Shows creativity by inventing names and characters, persistently searching for the right name (Scrooge), demonstrating imaginative skill.
Engages confidently and playfully with the character of Scrooge, showing ability to interact with his own creation and develop it further.
Momentarily distracted and unaware of Tara leaving, indicating a lapse of social awareness.
Throws open the door and rushes down the stairs at the sound of Mrs. Fisk’s scream to help her.
Waves the cage to shoo away the raven troubling Mrs. Fisk, showing concern for her comfort.
Laughs out loud, admiringly at Scrooge's cynical critique of Christmas, and speaks warmly about collaborating with him.
Eagerly embraces Scrooge's harsh, critical characterization, showing openness and creative enthusiasm.
Rapidly goes through his pre-writing ritual and starts writing furiously after engaging with Scrooge's dialogue.
Expresses frustration by pacing and gripping his hair earlier, suggesting difficulty before breakthrough.
Laughs out loud and admires Scrooge's harsh perspective, showing confident use of creative inspiration.
Winks at Young Charles, who stares up at him with adoration; expresses a wish for love and blessing on Christmas day.
Struggles helplessly when bailiffs take household goods due to debt, unable to comfort his crying son.
Warmly greets and interacts with his sister, nephew, and family members upon arriving home, showing recognition, interest, and friendliness.
Politely thanks and acknowledges the workman fixing the chandelier with sincere gratitude.
Confidently assures Forster he will finish the work on time despite doubts.
Politely and clearly interacts with household members and visitors, showing awareness and kindness.
Does not react negatively or show frustration about minor inconveniences (missing door knocker, repairs).
Offers to help Fanny during a difficult time and engages in gentle, humorous banter with her.
Expresses concern about financial insecurity but reacts with light humor and intimacy with family.

Tries to support Fanny emotionally and offers help during a difficult time.
Expresses frustration about financial instability and future uncertainty.
Engages in lighthearted banter and uses humor to deflect stress.
Gently hushes Kate to keep her from waking, showing consideration for her rest despite his own concern.
Encourages Scrooge to follow the Ghost of Christmas Past to learn something, showing patience and willingness to support others' growth.
Looks fearful and does not engage with the ghost, indicating hesitation or self-doubt but no negative social behavior.
Mr. Dickens tries to comfort young Charles by telling him not to cry and encouraging him to be strong despite their hardship.
Mr. Dickens tells young Charles to 'stand up tall' and calls him 'son of John Dickens, a Gentleman', trying to instill pride and resilience.
Mr. Dickens uses somewhat harsh phrases like 'Blood of iron, heart of ice' to encourage emotional toughness in his son.
Dickens wakens troubled from bad dreams but shares little about them with Kate, showing some emotional reserve.
Remembers and repeats 'Blood of iron, heart of ice' to steel himself emotionally after traumatic separation, showing mental resilience.
Tosses and turns at night due to bad dreams, indicating lingering emotional distress and difficulty coping.
Initially shrugs off discussing bad dreams, suggesting some emotional repression or avoidance rather than confronting issues.
Responds to Scrooge's harshness by gently reminding him of childhood and observing the market with curiosity and kindness.
Engages Scrooge in a patient and sincere conversation, encouraging him to see beyond the surface of the market and focus on the humanity present.
Invites Tara in, insists she sit and listen to him read despite her hesitation, shares his creative work warmly.
Spends time reading aloud to Tara, engages her imagination with enthusiasm.
Leaves Kate alone and bored upstairs, apparently absorbed in his own work and detached from his wife's company.
Presents the Ghost of Christmas Present to illustrate generosity and social realities through skillful storytelling.
Portrays Scrooge as initially lacking empathy and awareness about his clerk’s personal life, highlighting social critique.
Does not provide explicit direct actions by Dickens himself in this excerpt; competence inferred through narrative depiction.
Turns over the last page of the manuscript and acknowledges 'And that's as far as I've got.'
Engages with Tara thoughtfully when she asks how he makes a world come alive in his writing.
Appears pleased that his writing has moved someone emotionally, showing awareness of his work's impact.
Is wary when Scrooge approaches him with 'a word in your ear,' suggesting caution but also alertness.
Rejects Scrooge’s attempt to rationalize his character with market self-interest harshly ('No. No. And no.')

Engages thoughtfully with the emotional reactions of others, maintaining composure and guiding the conversation.

Reacts bitterly to the sight of the factory and its surroundings, expressing harsh negativity.
Expresses doubt and fear about finishing his book and writing again.
Recognizes his emotional state and shares his internal struggle with his friend Forster.
Refuses to leave the night outing to rest or seek comfort despite advice, showing emotional difficulty.

Shows protective and responsible attitude by buying and furnishing a house for his father and giving him an allowance.

Reflects on personal hardships of poverty and suffering from a young age, showing vulnerable honesty.
Confronts his father with intense emotion and clearly expresses his grievances about their past abuse and neglect.
Refuses to engage further with his father and shuts the door firmly behind him, showing emotional control and boundary-setting.

Shows visible vulnerability and heavy breathing after the confrontation, indicating emotional strain but not loss of composure.
Picks up the manuscript and insists to get back to work.

Attempts to assert control over the situation but fails to calm or guide the other characters effectively.
Throws the glass inkwell at the fireplace in a sudden movement, causing the room to empty.
Wakes with a start to find the room in disarray, indicating a lack of control or organization.
Bells down the stairs calling for Tara urgently, showing quick reactive decision-making.
Orders Mrs. Fisk to search for Tara and rehire her immediately, demonstrating decisiveness and taking charge to resolve a crisis.
Turns on Kate with blazing eyes, indicating emotional volatility.

Runs to stop his parents from leaving, insisting they not go and saying 'It’s what you haven’t done.' causing Mrs. Dickens to flinch.
Hesitates but then impulsively rushes out of the house, kisses Kate, and leaves abruptly.
Leaps over the barrier at the train station to catch his parents before they leave, and confronts them directly.
Laughs maniacally after being unable to immediately explain or understand his father's confusion.
Joyfully interacts with family, uses humor and warmth to defuse tension.
Recalls and acts on Christmas Carol manuscript promptly upon realizing its importance.
Manages to engage positively with the constable, showing social confidence.
Loses several manuscript pages to the wind, causing a chaotic chase.

Waits nervously and shows awe and sincere appreciation when receiving the printed book.
Dresses as a conjuror and performs magic tricks for children at a Christmas party.
Interrupts Forster politely to decline hearing a review of his book at the moment.
Smiles warmly, raises a glass in a inclusive toast to all guests including 'those on the way'.
Writes a book in only six weeks, impressing others with his rapid and skillful work.
Dresses as a conjuror and entertains children with magic tricks at a Christmas party, showing planning and social skill.
Responds to Forster's reading of a review with slight impatience ('Not now please, Forster...'), implying some self-consciousness or discomfort.
Confidently acknowledges praise from the group and raises a glass in a toast, demonstrating social confidence.
Raises a toast wishing everyone many merry Christmases, friendships, cheerful recollections, and heaven for all.

Successfully publishes and distributes 'The Carol' which generates excitement and joy among readers, showing skill and effectiveness in his work.

Shows mild frustration or sarcasm about high cost of mantelpiece but still agrees politely to pay later.

Reacts with agitation and muttering to himself about business and money concerns, showing preoccupation but not paralysis.
Is initially oblivious to family presence, distracted by his own thoughts and ideas.
Scribbles furiously and talks to himself like a man possessed, demonstrating intense focus and creative drive.
Paces and excitedly refers to his hastily scrawled notes, showing enthusiasm but some uncertainty about details.

Defends the spirit of Christmas as a time when people open their hearts and think sincerely of others as fellow human beings.
Displays rising temper when faced with skepticism and cynicism about Christmas and his book idea.

Dickens shows curiosity about Tara's reading by examining her Penny Dreadful and asks kindly where she learned to read.

Offers to trade Tara's sensational magazine for a more classic book, demonstrating thoughtfulness and generosity.
Initially tells Tara 'I'm not to be interrupted under any circumstances' in a brusque manner.

Leans in attentively, pen at the ready, indicating focus and preparedness in his creative work.
Engages in a calm, civil conversation with his father, managing personal interactions smoothly.
Does not appear confused or hesitant in the chaotic moment, but takes immediate charge, showcasing confidence.
Hands candlestick to his father promptly when requested.
Shows frustration by angrily rapping on the doorknocker.
Invites Marley in and listens to his story attentively.
Shows thoughtful reflection by carefully considering Marley’s warnings and moving closer to him, indicating engagement and sincerity.
Responds with short, somewhat detached lines like 'Indeed.' and 'You mean him, surely.' without evident emotional expressiveness.
Laughs with pleasure at the lively street scene and engages with moments of joy around him.
Unnerved and momentarily frozen by the papier mache bottle flyer, then abruptly leaves the scene to return to work.

Chooses not to respond to his father's teasing about procrastination, showing restraint and social awareness.
Insists on having Tara bring up the tray instead of Kate, showing decisiveness and control over the situation.
His satirical and blunt remarks cause awkward silences and mortify others, suggesting a lack of social tact.
Talks to himself in the mirror intensely, envisioning characters vividly to inspire his writing.
Invites Tara in and reads his manuscript aloud to her, demonstrating confidence and belief in his work.
Shows little awareness or consideration of his wife Kate's loneliness and boredom, potentially neglecting personal responsibilities.

Through portrayal of the Cratchit family and their modest yet joyful Christmas dinner, Dickens shows empathy and concern for the struggles of ordinary people, reflecting warmth in his narrative voice and social awareness.
Portrays Scrooge's initial coldness and ignorance towards his clerk's personal life, highlighting the lack of warmth in others to contrast with more positive traits.
Pleased that his writing has affected Tara emotionally, takes a sincere interest in her reaction.
Wary when Scrooge addresses him unexpectedly, showing caution or reserve rather than openness.
Despite past failures and debt, dismisses negativity and shows resilience, asserting he is still young and capable.
Takes initiative and leads the group by interpreting the Ghost's gesture and moving confidently towards the indicated door.
Responds calmly and thoughtfully to the mysterious and potentially frightening situation with the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, showing presence of mind.

Gently corrects harsh judgment about Tiny Tim's death, showing empathy.
Acknowledges Scrooge's selfishness but allows hope for change through others' belief.
Expresses doubt about Scrooge's ability to change, showing realism but no harshness.
Shows concern about his mother’s wellbeing after her long day at Kew and the unfinished newspaper article by his father.
Is a little afraid of his mother, indicating some emotional distance or tension.
Performs ritualistic preparation before writing, straightening desk and tidying manuscript, showing discipline and methodical behavior.
Experiences visible frustration and writer's block, grips his hair and struggles to write.
Confronts his father about unfinished newspaper article, showing assertiveness and concern for deadlines.
Appears somewhat afraid of his mother, suggesting a lack of confident interpersonal assertiveness in family context.
Tells his father it's time to go back to Devon as soon as possible, despite father's scowling presence.
Receives a reproachful look from Mrs. Dickens about being hard on his father and responds with a pointed 'Don't I?'.
Encourages the characters to run the scene again despite their groans, engaging collaboratively in his work.
Insists on control as the author, ignoring Scrooge's critical remarks in a somewhat dismissive manner.
Seeks help from Forster openly, showing vulnerability and trust.
Sits at desk and actively directs characters to run a scene again, showing control and engagement with his work.
Admits to working out the ending through repeated attempts rather than giving up, indicating persistence and problem-solving.
Refuses to acknowledge being blocked despite evident frustration and Scrooge character’s suggestion of writer’s block.
Seeks assistance from Forster when facing difficulty with a character, demonstrating self-awareness and willingness to improve.
Shows some denial or defensiveness when challenged by his own character, possibly indicating internal conflict or pressure.
Dismisses Forster's concern about Tiny Tim's fate and refuses to make the story hopeful, showing impatience and a lack of openness to others' feelings.
Acknowledges Forster sarcastically and dismisses his opinions, telling him his services are no longer required despite Forster acting as a friend.
Engages in a sharp exchange with Forster, dismissing advice that challenges his creative decisions.
Demonstrates confidence in his artistic vision by rejecting the suggestion to alter the story’s tone for commercial or emotional appeal.
Abruptly ends the conversation and 'fires' Forster, showing impatience and perhaps poor interpersonal judgement.
Throws open the door furious and orders Mrs. Fisk to take Tara away and make sure she never disturbs him again.
Delivers a profound, symbolic vision to Scrooge illustrating themes of loneliness and redemption.
Maintains control over the unfolding narrative and uses dramatic tension effectively to evoke transformation in Scrooge.
Is momentarily shocked and alone after the vision ends, showing a human reaction but quickly recovers to continue work.
Rushes with Forster to deliver the final manuscript to the printing compositor, demonstrating quick thinking and urgency to complete the work on time.
Negotiates with Mr. Grub to try to include the final chapter despite compositors' reluctance, showing persistence and awareness of printing constraints.
Waits nervously for the finished book but maintains composure and acknowledges the completed work with an expression of satisfaction and awe.
